data.title: #36. Should I Change My Last Name?
data.text:
A few weeks ago, Paul and I went out to dinner with my parents at a little French restaurant in downtown St. Paul that my mom absolutely raved about from the moment we walked in. While we were drinking red wine waiting for our main courses to arrive, she not-so-casually lobbed a question across the table: â€œSo, have you decided whether or not youâ€™re changing your last name yet?â€

There are over 3 million people with the last name â€œJohnsonâ€ in the worldâ€“ itâ€™s also the most common last name in the state of Minnesota, and the second most common in the United States. My proposed new last name may be extremely popular in the state I live in (itâ€™s the fourth most common after Johnson, Anderson, and Nelson), but there are only 234,641 recorded instances of the last name â€œOlsonâ€ worldwide.

There are a million reasons to want to keep or change your name, and marriage isnâ€™t even necessarily the precipitating factor for many of those feelings. Iâ€™ve been talking about changing my name since I was in middle schoolâ€“first I dabbled with spelling my first name â€œKellieâ€ and then â€œKeli,â€ both of which felt off-brand and didnâ€™t stickâ€“and then in high school, I more or less accepted my somewhat bland first name with its usual spelling and started fantasizing about changing my last name when I got married instead. Iâ€™ve tried on the last name of basically every person Iâ€™ve ever dated, wondering how it would sound to introduce myself as that person; a brand-new identity. Marriage has always felt to me like a convenient excuse to change my name in a way that wouldnâ€™t read to other people as â€œweirdâ€â€“but really, the desire to change my name in some way has always been about expressing my identity in a way that feels more interesting than the admittedly banal name I was born with.

Whatâ€™s in a name? Juliet said that â€œa rose by any other name would smell as sweetâ€ when referring to her lover, who belonged to her familyâ€™s rival house. I like the sentiment of that world-famous phraseâ€“that Juliet doesnâ€™t give a fuck what Romeoâ€™s last name is; she loves him, and thatâ€™s thatâ€“but I think names can actually affect our perceptions of people, our identities, and even our personalities. My mom named me after a popular girl she went to high school with who she didnâ€™t know but admired from afarâ€“a cheerleaderâ€“and thatâ€™s always been the image the name â€œKellyâ€ has conjured for me, though the association has dulled over time.

My full name is about as cookie cutter as it gets. Try Googling me without any other identifying factor! You wonâ€™t get very farâ€“there are literally thousands of people with my name out there. I hate the relative obscurity and blend-into-the-crowd misfortune that comes with a common first and last name combo, and I have pretty much always wanted to change mine. Maybe I should have, years ago, when it had absolutely nothing to do with marriage, and everything to do with an expression of the â€œself.â€ But here we are, with a name Iâ€™ve now had for 34 years, and a forthcoming marriage as the precipitating factor for a potential new identifier.

To change, or not to change? That is the question, and a decision that every person who gets married has to make at some point. Typically, the people mostly likely to consider a name change precipitated by marriage are women. Given the dismal history of women taking their husbandâ€™s last names and its shockingly Handmaidâ€™s Tale-ian nature, a woman keeping her last name is certainly the most â€œfeministâ€ option available (and the easiest), but itâ€™s a route that only 20-30% of American women who are married to men currently take. (For LGBTQIA+ couples, though, half choose one partnerâ€™s name.)

Hereâ€™s a fun statistic that will really freak you out: As recently as the 1970s, women in the U.S. were required to use their husbandâ€™s last name to vote, bank, or get a passport, according to state laws. Those laws were changed in 1975, but surprisingly, the percentage of women keeping their last names after marriage really hasnâ€™t changed that much since the 70s, when the number was around 17%. Instead of women feeling liberated and empowered to keep their names after 1975, the percentage actually dropped back down to pre-1970s levelsâ€“14%â€“in the conservative 1980s. Shockingly, the amount of women keeping their last names only passed the 20% mark as recently as the 2010s.

In general, itâ€™s white women who get married at a later age, who are less religious, and donâ€™t have (or plan to have) kids who keep their last names. (Hi, itâ€™s me, Iâ€™m the problem.)

A 2013 article I dug up from Womenâ€™s Health has some really fun stats and quotes in it about how men feel about women keeping their last names that all make me want to barf:

63 percent of Menâ€™s Health followers said they would be upset if their wives kept their maiden names:

â€œOne family, one name. If she didn't take my name, I'd seriously question her faith in us lasting as a couple. And I don't want hyphenated kids.â€

â€œI believe the purpose of marriage is raising children, and children take their father's name (as a way of identifying paternity). Mothers always have a special bond, carrying their young. Fathers donâ€™t, so [passing on our name] is our compensation.â€

â€œIt sounds like she's trying to hang onto her "single person" identity and not identify with the fact that she's married now.â€

â€œHyphenation is a direct â€œf*ck youâ€ to a manâ€™s masculinityâ€¦ it elevates his father-in-lawâ€™s manhood over his own.â€

96 percent of Menâ€™s Health followers said they wouldnâ€™t take a womanâ€™s last name if she asked them to:

â€œMy name is part of who I am.â€

â€œCall it pride or ego, whatever. Itâ€™s not happening.â€

â€œ[I wouldnâ€™t take a womanâ€™s last name if she asked.] Admittedly, this feels hypocritical, though.â€

â€œThatâ€™s just not manly to me.â€

Love that for us.

The experiences of married people in my orbit truly runs the gamut. I have friends who have kept their name on feminist principle, kept their name out of laziness, changed their name for the sake of tradition (or for the benefit of their future children), changed their last name and used theirs as a middle name, chosen a new last name together with their partner, hyphenated their last names, kept their name at work but changed it legally, and kept their name for now but plan to change it eventually. I also have a friend who is considering taking his wifeâ€™s last name when they have kidsâ€“which is currently so uncommon it represents a choice that only 3% of heterosexual, married men makeâ€“because his wifeâ€™s last name just sounds way cooler than his does.

Right now, Iâ€™m leaning towards keeping my name. First of all, becoming Kelly Johnson-Olson or Kelly Jolson would be absolutely ridiculous. Letâ€™s be serious, lol. And after years of imagining myself as someone else and a close brush with marrying the wrong person, Iâ€™ve found a sort of peace with who I am, and the name that has been with me through it all.

If I keep my last name, Iâ€™ll have to learn to accept that people will still address us as â€œThe Olsonsâ€ or accidentally call me by the wrong name, and I know this because itâ€™s already started happening to me, and we arenâ€™t even married yet. It might be totally innocentâ€“an easy mistake you might not think twice aboutâ€“but itâ€™s also indicative of the fact that most people will just assume Iâ€™m going to change my last name eventually.

Like it or not, a married, heterosexual woman taking her husbandâ€™s last name is the â€œdefaultâ€ option, and itâ€™s a much surer bet to assume Iâ€™ll change my name. And maybe I accept that most people are a little lazy and donâ€™t want to go through the extra effort to find out what my last name is, but I also think it should be a courtesy among friends and acquaintances that people shouldnâ€™t just assume. For example, I sent out a save-the-date a few weeks ago to a newer friend and her husband (who have different last names), and after receiving it, they asked me how I figured out his last name since they couldnâ€™t remember it ever having come up, and theyâ€™re both not on Instagram. I answered, â€œWell I stalked you on LinkedIn, of course,â€ and they both laughed. I wanted to get his name right! Why donâ€™t we always afford women the same courtesy?

Four years ago, during my previous and ultimately failed engagement, I received a wedding invitation in the mail from one of our friends. It was addressed to: â€œThe Future Mr. and Mrs. [Exâ€™s Last Name]â€ in beautiful, delicate calligraphy. While I think the intention behind this likely very innocent and well-meaning choice was to show excitement and support for us, the impact on my mental state was considerably less positive. It made me feel erased. No part of my actual name was on the invitation at all, and Iâ€™m sure the sender didnâ€™t know this at the time, but the relationship was in a dark place. Seeing his name on the invitation instead of mine was like a bucket of cold water being thrown in my face. Is this your future? Is this who you are going to become? And are you okay with that?

Keeping my last name would probably condemn me to a future of corrections, repeating â€œactually, my last name is Johnsonâ€ to people over and over until I die. Eventually it wonâ€™t be with friends and acquaintances; it will just be random people Iâ€™ll meet along the road of life who go for the easy answer. Weâ€™ll pull up to a hotel that Paul has booked for us, Iâ€™ll be driving, and theyâ€™ll address me as â€œMrs. Olsonâ€ when I step out of the car. I know this because it has already happened. And it will keep happening until the majority of married women stop changing their last names. Which may be never, or at least not in my lifetime.

I also canâ€™t help but wonder if, in the not-so-distant future, we will continue to use terms like â€œhusbandâ€ and â€œwifeâ€â€“words many people my age seem to chew on like they donâ€™t taste quite rightâ€“or designations like â€œMrsâ€ and â€œMsâ€ and â€œMiss.â€ Why are there three options for women depending on her age and whether or not sheâ€™s married, when a manâ€™s designation never changes?

Even the term â€œmaiden nameâ€ really rubs me the wrong way, which is why youâ€™ll see Iâ€™ve somehow managed to avoid it this entire issue. â€œMaidenâ€ is a word that means many things, including a young, virginal, unmarried woman; a maidservant; and something that is new, fresh, and untried. Umâ€¦ no. I might eventually get comfortable with saying Iâ€™m a wife, but calling Johnson my maiden name is where I draw the fucking line.

So tell meâ€“what did you do? Did you change your last name, or keep it? Do you regret it? Come tell me your experiences with name changes in the comments; I am genuinely dying to know!!

I can tell you one thing for sureâ€“no matter what I decide to do, if I got a dollar every time future me meets a new person who accidentally or accurately addresses me as â€œMrs. Olsonâ€ simply because itâ€™s the default guess in our society, Iâ€™d probably die rich.

K bye,

P.S. Iâ€™ll leave you with the full text of Julietâ€™s little rant about names, because itâ€™s a classic:

O Romeo, Romeo! wherefore art thou Romeo?

Deny thy father and refuse thy name;

Or, if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love,

And I'll no longer be a Capulet.

'Tis but thy name that is my enemy;

Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.

What's Montague? It is nor hand, nor foot,

Nor arm, nor face, nor any other part

Belonging to a man. O, be some other name!

What's in a name? That which we call a rose

By any other name would smell as sweet;

So Romeo would, were he not Romeo call'd,

Retain that dear perfection which he owes

Without that title. Romeo, doff thy name,

And for that name which is no part of thee

Take all myself.
